column1: A prefectural-level municipality (Chinese: 地级市)
column2: prefectural-level city or prefectural city; formerly known as province-administrated city (Chinese: 省辖市) from 1949 to 1983
column3: is an administrative division of the People's Republic of China (PRC)
column4: ranking below a province and above a county in China's administrative structure. Prefectural level cities form the second level of the administrative structure (alongside prefectures
column5: leagues and autonomous prefectures). Administrative chiefs (mayors) of prefectural level cities generally have the same rank as a division chief (Chinese: 司长) of a national ministry. Since the 1980s
column6: most former prefectures have been renamed into prefectural level cities.

column1: A prefectural level city is a "city" (Chinese: 市; pinyin: shì) and "prefecture" (Chinese: 地区; pinyin: dìqū) that have been merged into one consolidated and unified jurisdiction. As such it is simultaneously a city
column2: which is a municipal entry with subordinate districts
column3: and a prefecture with subordinate county-level cities and counties which is an administrative division of a province.

column1: A prefectural level city is often not a "city" in the usual sense of the term (i.e.
column3: but instead an administrative unit comprising
column5: a main central urban area (a city in the usual sense
column6: usually with the same name as the prefectural level city)
column7: and its much larger surrounding rural area containing many smaller cities
column8: towns and villages. The larger prefectural level cities span over 100 kilometres (62 mi).

column1: Prefectural level cities nearly always contain multiple counties
column3: and other such sub-divisions. This results from the fact that the formerly predominant prefectures
column4: which prefectural level cities have mostly replaced
column5: were themselves large administrative units containing cities
column7: and rural areas. To distinguish a prefectural level city from its actual urban area (city in the strict sense)
column8: the term 市区 shìqū ("urban area")

column1: The first prefectural level cities were created on 5 November 1983. Over the following two decades
column2: prefectural level cities have come to replace the vast majority of Chinese prefectures; the process is still ongoing.

column1: Most provinces are composed entirely or nearly entirely of prefectural level cities. Of the 22 provinces and 5 autonomous regions of the PRC
column12: Inner Mongolia) have at least one or more second level or prefectural level divisions that are not prefectural level cities.

column1: Criteria that a prefecture must meet to become a prefectural level city:
An urban centre with a non-rural population over 250
gross output of value of industry of 200
the output of tertiary industry supersedes that of primary industry
column2: contributing over 35% of the GDP15 large prefectural level cities have been granted the status of sub-provincial city
column3: which gives them much greater autonomy.

column1: Shijiazhuang and Zhengzhou are the largest prefectural level cities with populations approaching or exceeding some sub-provincial cities.
A sub-prefecture-level city is a county-level city with powers approaching those of prefectural level cities.
== Classification ==
There are total of three classification of prefecture-level city:
Regular prefectural level city which consist of counties
Consolidated district-governed prefectural level city which only consist of districts as it subdivisions.
Currently there are only 13 cities are under this classification: Ezhou
Prefectural level city with no county-level divisions (Direct-piped city) are cities that do not govern any county-level divisions such as counties
Currently there are only 4 cities are under this classification: Danzhou

column1: This convention may lead to difficulty in the identification of places mentioned in older sources. For example
column2: Guo Moruo writes that he was born in Town of Shawan
column4: and attended primary school in Town of Jiading. A modern map is unlikely to show either town: Shawan
column7: because it is the seat of City of Leshan
column8: and is therefore indicated on the map by a point labelled "Leshan." A more detailed map would show Shawan as a district within City of Leshan
column9: but Jiading would still be missing.

column1: Statistics of China such as population and industrial activity are generally reported along prefectural city lines. Thus
column2: the relatively unknown City of Huangshi has 2.5 million residents
column5: the city covers an area almost 100 kilometers across. Furthermore
